bibl.title: Letter from William C. Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 30, 1906

div1.p: Gorgas writes about a planned increase in the Canal Zone medical force, and encloses correspondence recommending physician Alexander Murray for service in Panama.

div1.head: Letter from William C. Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 30, 1906
div1.opener:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
----
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, C. Z.
July 30, 1906.
Maj. Jefferson R. Kean, U.S.A.,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Kean:-
div1.p:
Please find enclosed correspondence enc. 1; enc. 2 which
will explain itself. The Commission have decided to give us
an increase in medical force and I think they would apply
for Dr. Murray if I asked them. He would get the fifty
percent increase, and nothing more, and would probably be
assigned to duty in some of the laborers camps. A rough
life, such as our frontier service in the old time. Our
force is increasing and we have at present 1500 sick in
hospitals, but the force is so scattered that we require a
considerable number of doctors. We have at present 86.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W. C. Gorgas,
Chief Sanitary Officer. H
